hints_html:
Use the integral p test.

If you do not know how to use the integral p test, estimate the integral with a lower bound first.
hints_latex:

hints_raw:
Use the integral ''p'' test.
If you do not know how to use the integral ''p'' test, estimate the integral with a lower bound first.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
The difference between the highest exponents is 3 - 2 = 1. By the intergral p test (with p = 1) this integral diverges.

More precisely we estimate the integral with

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^\infty\frac{x^2}{x^3 + 2x + 5}dx > \int_1^\infty\frac{x^2}{x^3 + 2x^3 + 5x^3}dx = \frac18\int_1^\infty\frac1xdx\end{aligned}\]

Here we see exactly how to use the integral p test. We also can continue with the anti-derivative

\[\begin{aligned} \frac18\int_1^\infty\frac1xdx = \frac18\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow\infty}[\text{ln}(x)]_1^\alpha = \frac18\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow\infty}\text{ln}(\alpha)=\infty\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The difference between the highest exponents is 3 - 2 = 1. By the intergral ''p'' test (with ''p'' = 1) this integral diverges.

More precisely we estimate the integral with
:<math>
\int_1^\infty\frac{x^2}{x^3 + 2x + 5}dx > \int_1^\infty\frac{x^2}{x^3 + 2x^3 + 5x^3}dx = \frac18\int_1^\infty\frac1xdx
</math>

Here we see exactly how to use the integral ''p'' test. We also can continue with the anti-derivative
:<math>
\frac18\int_1^\infty\frac1xdx = \frac18\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow\infty}[\text{ln}(x)]_1^\alpha = \frac18\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow\infty}\text{ln}(\alpha)=\infty
</math>
statement_html:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be considered for this problem).

Does the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^{\infty} \frac {x^2}{x^3+2x+5} \,dx\end{aligned}\]

converge?

A. Converge.

B. Diverge.
